report_title: Healthcare Staff Recruitment Agencies in the US
executive_summary: Healthcare staff recruitment agencies rely on the strength of the sector's labor market. In recent years, structural and demographic trends across the healthcare industry have affected both the composition of its workforce and overall demand for healthcare professionals. Recruitment agencies have played a role in helping healthcare providers navigate these changes, which are driven by two main factors: the expanding needs of a growing over-65 population and substantial shortages of healthcare workers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Healthcare Sector Trends are Benefiting Healthcare Staff Recruitment Agencies
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, healthcare providers have become increasingly reliant on recruiting agencies. Structural and demographic trends across the sector are shifting the composition of the industry's workforce and increasing the need for healthcare professionals.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Healthcare Providers Look to Recruitment Agencies to Navigate a Complex Labor Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: At the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, the health sector saw a sharp decline in employment as utilization of healthcare services fell. However, the underlying factors that drive demand for recruitment stayed in place. Lower employment needs caused agencies' revenue to fall in 2020, but a surge in demand led to a more than 20.0% jump in revenue and a spike in rehiring activity in 2021. While health sector employment rebounded, it brought new challenges for providers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Incumbent Recruitment Agencies Eye Consolidation to Reach New Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Robust growth for recruitment agencies spurs consolidation activity. Incumbent agencies seek acquisitions of smaller, regional recruitment agencies to boost capacity and expand their geographic reach. This can be a particularly effective way to reach new markets that are difficult to penetrate organically.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Rise of Travel Nursing Has Significantly Impacted the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Travel nursing has become a more attractive option for nurses, as it offers them the opportunity to work in different locations and earn higher salaries. This has made it more difficult for agencies to recruit nurses for permanent positions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Increasing healthcare expenditure will continue to facilitate building a strong healthcare labor market. Because healthcare staff recruitment agencies' growth is linked to the state of the sector's labor market, recruitment agencies will reap the benefits of a growing workforce.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: RECRUITMENT AGENCIES WILL REMAIN CRUCIAL TO ALLEVIATING STAFFING SHORTAGES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Healthcare providers will continue outsourcing to recruitment agencies to address chronic healthcare personnel shortages that have existed since before the pandemic.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GROWTH OPPORTUNITIES ATTRACT INCUMBENTS AND NEW ENTRANTS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Staffing shortages in the health sector are prevalent across markets, ranging from mental health clinics to hospitals and physical therapy practices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technology and the Hiring Process Will Become More Entwined
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Tech advances will shape how healthcare staffing operates going forward. Staffing agencies' tech adoption will focus on AI, data analytics and targeted software programs to improve nearly every hiring process.

industry_definition: A healthcare staff recruitment agency is an organization that connects healthcare facilities (hospitals, clinics, nursing homes) with qualified healthcare professionals (doctors, nurses, medical technicians, administrative personnel).

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid

key_trends: An agency's reputation is critical. Healthcare providers partner with recruitment agencies that have proven track records of providing quality candidates.

Digital tools streamline the recruitment process. Recruitment agencies that leverage innovative technologies are gaining advantage. Several agencies are acquiring tech companies to beef up their tech profiles.
Demographic and structural trends in healthcare support the need for a robust workforce. Healthcare recruitment agencies rely on the well-being of the health sector's labor market.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Hospitals and health systems are healthcare institutions providing patient treatment, both inpatient and outpatient, with specialized medical and nursing staff.
Health groups are integrated healthcare provider networks. A health group can include hospitals, outpatient centers, urgent care centers, nursing services, hospice and other healthcare facilities.
A community health center (CHC) is a nonprofit healthcare facility providing comprehensive primary and preventive medical, dental and mental health services.
Clinical facilities are specialized facilities that conduct clinical trials to evaluate the safety and efficacy of new drugs, medical devices and treatments.
Other markets include independent physician offices, research facilities, urgent care centers, retail clinics and home health providers.

products_and_services.product_description: Nurse practitioners are healthcare professionals qualified to provide primary and specialty medical care.

Family medicine physicians, also known as primary care physicians or general practitioners, focus on the healthcare of individuals of all ages and genders regardless of disease or location of the ailment.

tier_1_buyers: Emergency & Other Outpatient Care Centers in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Rising health expenditure causes demand for many healthcare professionals to increase, leading more providers to outsource hiring to recruitment agencies. Drops in total health expenditure pose a potential threat to the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region houses many healthcare facilities to meet the medical needs of its large population. Florida has the largest number of agencies in the region due to its large population size and high percentage of senior citizens.

The Mid-Atlantic's share of agencies mirrors its share of the population. New York and Pennsylvania contribute substantially to this percentage. Densely populated cities in New York influence the number of agencies in the state.

The high concentration of agencies in the West region is primarily a result of population distribution. California has the highest number of agencies in this region and the United States due to its large population and over 350 hospitals.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The EEOC enforces federal laws that prohibit employment discrimination. Healthcare staff recruitment agencies can't discriminate against candidates based on age, disability, national origin, sex, race or religion.

Recruiters can't ask about a candidate's pay history in their current position or previous position; 14 states have some iteration of pay disclosure laws. Ten states have adopted similar pay transparency laws, which require employers to disclose expected compensation ranges in advertisements for jobs, promotions and transfers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: A M E R I C A N S  W I T H  D I S A B I L I T I E S  A C T  ( A D A )
regulations_points.regulation_description: Healthcare staff recruitment agencies can't ask a job applicant about a mental or medical disability. The ADA provides job applicants with disabilities equal opportunities in the workplace. Recruitment agencies working with an employer with 15 or more employees are subject to ADA requirements.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Recruitment agencies must comply with various laws and regulations covering licensing, transparency and nondiscriminatory hiring practices. Failing to meet these standards risks a new agency's credibility, hurting its ability to compete moving forward.

Recruitment agencies can specialize in a specific healthcare industry or personnel type. Nationwide shortages in some areas, like skilled nursing care, could provide new agencies with more opportunities.
A new agency doesn't face substantial start-up costs. A more significant barrier is a lack of results, connections and reputation compared to incumbent agencies.

basis_points.basis_description: An agency's reputation is critical. Healthcare providers partner with recruitment agencies that have proven track records of providing quality candidates.

Digital tools streamline the recruitment process. Recruitment agencies that leverage innovative technologies are gaining advantage. Several agencies are acquiring tech companies to beef up their tech profiles.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Healthcare staff recruitment agencies source job applicants, including nurses and physicians, for various healthcare providers (e.g. hospitals, mental health clinics, nursing homes). Each provider has specific staffing needs – an outcome of budget constraints, geographic differences, regulatory requirements and scope of services. Fragmentation makes it difficult for any recruitment agency to develop a substantial market share.

Competition in healthcare recruitment can make it difficult for an agency to scale. Low switching costs make switching between recruiters easier for healthcare providers, while a healthcare provider can also develop in-house recruitment as needed.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Mounting Importance of Healthcare Recruiters Drives Wage Growth
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: A healthcare staff recruitment agency is only as good as the strength of its recruiters. Without knowledgeable and experienced recruiters who can navigate an evolving health sector and source top-tier candidates, an agency would lack results and credibility.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Despite rising investment into recruitment software, healthcare recruitment agencies rely on recruiters to source, interview and negotiate with job seekers.

The recruitment process is more dependent on labor than capital. Talented recruiters must find qualified professionals and match them with hiring healthcare providers. AI and recruitment software investments have raised capital requirements, but labor still far exceeds this cost.

volatility_points.volatility_title: An Unprecedented Healthcare Labor Market Fosters Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Healthcare providers are outsourcing to healthcare staff recruitment agencies to solve the healthcare sector's robust staffing challenges.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Healthcare recruitment agencies can be sensitive to health employment fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: While healthcare providers' importance to public health can help limit their volatility in the job market, the industry can still struggle to manage the ebbs and flows of employment trends.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: PREDICTIVE ANALYTICS CAN RESULT IN BETTER MATCHES
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Healthcare recruitment agencies can use predictive analytics to identify the most qualified candidates for a job based on their past performance, skills, experience and other relevant factors.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE RECRUITMENT STREAMLINES THE SELECTION PROCESS
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Recruitment agencies can implement artificial intelligence (AI) to automate candidate sourcing and screening. AI-enabled tools can assess an applicant's skills and qualifications more accurately.

FAQs.question: Do regulations pertinent to your business vary from state to state?
FAQs.answer: Different states have different licensing requirements for healthcare workers.

FAQs.question: Is your business responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry must protect the information of their employees.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: A majority of industry customers pay through contracts.

FAQs.question: How quickly can your company pay off the money owed to its suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies have low capital and purchase costs.

FAQs.question: Do you actively maintain contact with those that require your services? How could you cultivate more relationships?
FAQs.answer: Developing contacts in various hospitals and healthcare facilities is essential for identifying and placing suitable candidates.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? Are your wages competitive?
FAQs.answer: Hiring and retaining knowledgeable and experienced recruitment agents with a strong connection to potential clientele is essential for operator success.

FAQs.question: What is your process for screening for individuals with good communication and interpersonal skills? How can you improve these methods?
FAQs.answer: Good communication and interpersonal skills combined with industry knowledge are important in retaining clients, interviewing job applicants and negotiating contracts.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor unemployment rates to plan your business accordingly? How have employment rates affected your revenue?
FAQs.answer: This industry is sensitive to the level of employment in the overall economy.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your patients qualify for Medicare or Medicaid? Have shifts in funding affected you significantly in the past?
FAQs.answer: Federal and state funding of Medicare and Medicaid, coupled with the government-determined terms of access to these reimbursement programs, affect demand for healthcare services.

FAQs.question: Does your revenue trend in line with overall health spending?
FAQs.answer: Total health expenditure includes public and private spending on activities that promote health and prevent disease, as well as healthcare facility services.
